repnme.cdata!: Papua New Guinea - Transport Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Transport Improvement Project (TIP) in
            Papua New Guinea. The objectives of the TIP were to: (a)
            improve land transport through the reconstruction, upgrading
            and maintenance of national roads, and the reduction of
            vehicle operating costs;( b) enhance air transport through
            ground equipment replacement, improvement of safety
            standards and resealing and regravelling of air
            strips,taxiways and aprons;( c) improve efficiency of road
            maintenance through the provision of road maintenanc
            equipment and materials;and (d) strengthen the sector
            institutions and improve of the domestic construction
            industry through provision of technical advisory services
            and training of local staff. Bank's performance was
            satisfactory. Borrower's performance was deficient. The
            key lessons learned were as follows: (i) within the
            customary and cultural procedures for acquiring land the
            State needs to develop a system which will remove the
            situations which disrupt all aspects of infrastructur
            development; (ii) when a loan is agreed to, the commitment
            of the Borrower to provide its share of the funds has to be
            maintained; and (iii) depending on the number of World Bank
            Loans current in Papua New Guinea at any one time,
            application and administration of the loan could be improved
            by the presence of an authorised Bank representative in
            Papua New Guinea.

repnme.cdata!: Papua New Guinea - Transport Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Transport
            Improvement Project are to (a) improve land transport; (b)
            enhance improvement of air transport; (c) improve efficiency
            of road maintenance; and (d) strengthen institution building
            and improve the domestic construction industry.  To achieve
            these objectives, the project includes several components.
            They comprise (a) reconstruction and upgrading of about 80
            km of national roads; (b) rehabilitation and replacement of
            about 50 bridges totaling about 1100 linear meters; (c)
            regravelling of about 500 km of national gravel roads; and
            (d) provision of road maintenance equipment and materials.
            The project further involves (e) replacement of
            navigational, meteorological and communication equipment at
            14 national airports, resealing/regravelling of runways,
            taxiways and aprons at 16 airports, rehabilitation and
            improvement of drainage works and fire stations at four
            airports.  It also includes (f) technical assistance to the
            Department of Works (DW), Department of Transport (DT) and
            Department of Civil Aviation and Tourism (DCAT); and (g)
            on-the-job, local and overseas training of DW, DT and DCAT staff.
